awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Dependable High Performance Scientific Computing at Extreme Scale  via Algorithmic Fault Tolerance
awd_abstract_narration:
Extreme scale high-end computing platforms are expected to be available before 2020 and will have 100 million to 1 billion CPU cores. Due to the large number of components in these platforms, the probability that errors occur during the execution of an extreme scale application is expected to be much higher than observed today. The goal of this CAREER research project is to develop highly efficient techniques to detect, locate, and correct both soft and hard errors according to the specific characteristics of an algorithm. The target algorithms include (1) Krylov subspace methods for solving sparse linear systems and eigenvalue problems; (2) Direct methods for solving dense linear systems and eigenvalue problems; and (3) Newton's method for solving systems of non-linear equations.
 
This project will create significant education outcomes by integrating the following four components: (1) establishing a supercomputing research laboratory to support senior design projects and REU, enhance graduate education and research, and demonstrate highly dependable applications on high-end computing platforms; (2) enriching the teaching of both undergraduate and graduate courses by integrating fault tolerance and high performance computing into the courses; (3) increasing minority  students involvement by encouraging minority students to pursue graduate degrees in computing; and (4) offering free workshops to K-12 teachers and students.

por.por_cntn:
A supercomputer is a computer with a high level of performance compared to a general-purpose computer. The next generation supercomputers available soon will have one hundred million to one billion computing cores. Due to the large number of computing cores in these computers, the probability that an error occurs in these computers is expected to be much higher than a desktop computer. When an error occurs, if the affected application continues working but produces incorrect computation results, the error is called as a soft error. If the affected application stops working, the error is called as a hard error.


Soft errors are often tolerated offline by checking computation results after the computation is done. This project designed novel online fault tolerance techniques to detect and correct soft errors at early stages in the middle of the computation so that higher efficiency can be achieved by stopping and correcting the corrupted computations in a more timely manner.


Hard errors are often tolerated by checkpoint. This project designed novel algorithmic fault tolerance techniques to tolerate hard errors in widely used scientific computing algorithms without checkpoint. Because neither checkpoint nor rollback is necessary, the proposed techniques will be highly efficient and have a good potential to scale to extreme scale and beyond. The target algorithms this project addresses have been frequently used to solve both linear and non-linear equations as well as eigen-value problems. Because these algorithms have been widely used by today's scientists and engineers from many different fields, the fault tolerance techniques developed in this project will benefit a large number of users and a wide range of fields.


Except the above research outcomes, through the support of this project, a supercomputing research laboratory has been established to support graduate education and enhance undergraduate senior design projects. This project has also helped to train hispanic minority students, female underrepresented students, and K12 high school students. The research results from this project have been presented at major conference meetings and incorporated into regular teaching.
